      37             : /* miniz.c v1.15 - public domain deflate/inflate, zlib-subset, ZIP reading/writing/appending, PNG
      38             :    writing See "unlicense" statement at the end of this file. Rich Geldreich <richgel99@gmail.com>,
      39             :    last updated Oct. 13, 2013 Implements RFC 1950: http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1950.txt and RFC 1951:
      40             :    http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1951.txt
      41             : 
      42             :    Most API's defined in miniz.c are optional. For example, to disable the archive related functions
      43             :    just define MINIZ_NO_ARCHIVE_APIS, or to get rid of all stdio usage define MINIZ_NO_STDIO (see
      44             :    the list below for more macros).

     112             :    a potentially large drop in throughput on some files). 5/15/11 v1.09 - Initial stable release.
     113             : 
     114             :    * Low-level Deflate/Inflate implementation notes:
     115             : 
     116             :      Compression: Use the "tdefl" API's. The compressor supports raw, static, and dynamic blocks,
     117             :    lazy or greedy parsing, match length filtering, RLE-only, and Huffman-only streams. It performs
     118             :    and compresses approximately as well as zlib.
     119             : 
     120             :      Decompression: Use the "tinfl" API's. The entire decompressor is implemented as a single
     121             :    function coroutine: see tinfl_decompress(). It supports decompression into a 32KB (or larger
     122             :    power of 2) wrapping buffer, or into a memory block large enough to hold the entire file.
     123             : 
     124             :      The low-level tdefl/tinfl API's do not make any use of dynamic memory allocation.
     125             : 
     126             :    * zlib-style API notes:
     127             : 
     128             :      miniz.c implements a fairly large subset of zlib. There's enough functionality present for it
     129             :    to be a drop-in zlib replacement in many apps: The z_stream struct, optional memory allocation
     130             :    callbacks deflateInit/deflateInit2/deflate/deflateReset/deflateEnd/deflateBound
     131             :         inflateInit/inflateInit2/inflate/inflateEnd
     132             :         compress, compress2, compressBound, uncompress
     133             :         CRC-32, Adler-32 - Using modern, minimal code size, CPU cache friendly routines.
     134             :         Supports raw deflate streams or standard zlib streams with adler-32 checking.
     135             : 
     136             :      Limitations:
     137             :       The callback API's are not implemented yet. No support for gzip headers or zlib static
     138             :    dictionaries. I've tried to closely emulate zlib's various flavors of stream flushing and return
     139             :    status codes, but there are no guarantees that miniz.c pulls this off perfectly.
     140             : 
     141             :    * PNG writing: See the tdefl_write_image_to_png_file_in_memory() function, originally written by
     142             :      Alex Evans. Supports 1-4 bytes/pixel images.
     143             : 
     144             :    * ZIP archive API notes:
     145             : 
     146             :      The ZIP archive API's where designed with simplicity and efficiency in mind, with just enough
     147             :    abstraction to get the job done with minimal fuss. There are simple API's to retrieve file
     148             :    information, read files from existing archives, create new archives, append new files to existing
     149             :    archives, or clone archive data from one archive to another. It supports archives located in
     150             :    memory or the heap, on disk (using stdio.h), or you can specify custom file read/write callbacks.
     151             : 
     152             :      - Archive reading: Just call this function to read a single file from a disk archive:
     153             : 
     154             :       void *mz_zip_extract_archive_file_to_heap(const char *pZip_filename, const char
     155             :    *pArchive_name, size_t *pSize, mz_uint zip_flags);
     156             : 
     157             :      For more complex cases, use the "mz_zip_reader" functions. Upon opening an archive, the entire
     158             :    central directory is located and read as-is into memory, and subsequent file access only occurs
     159             :    when reading individual files.
     160             : 
     161             :      - Archives file scanning: The simple way is to use this function to scan a loaded archive for a
     162             :    specific file:
     163             : 
     164             :      int mz_zip_reader_locate_file(mz_zip_archive *pZip, const char *pName, const char *pComment,
     165             :    mz_uint flags);
     166             : 
     167             :      The locate operation can optionally check file comments too, which (as one example) can be used
     168             :    to identify multiple versions of the same file in an archive. This function uses a simple linear
     169             :    search through the central directory, so it's not very fast.
     170             : 
     171             :      Alternately, you can iterate through all the files in an archive (using
     172             :    mz_zip_reader_get_num_files()) and retrieve detailed info on each file by calling
     173             :    mz_zip_reader_file_stat().
     174             : 
     175             :      - Archive creation: Use the "mz_zip_writer" functions. The ZIP writer immediately writes
     176             :    compressed file data to disk and builds an exact image of the central directory in memory. The
     177             :    central directory image is written all at once at the end of the archive file when the archive is
     178             :    finalized.
     179             : 
     180             :      The archive writer can optionally align each file's local header and file data to any power of
     181             :    2 alignment, which can be useful when the archive will be read from optical media. Also, the
     182             :    writer supports placing arbitrary data blobs at the very beginning of ZIP archives. Archives
     183             :    written using either feature are still readable by any ZIP tool.
     184             : 
     185             :      - Archive appending: The simple way to add a single file to an archive is to call this
     186             :    function:
     187             : 
     188             :       mz_bool mz_zip_add_mem_to_archive_file_in_place(const char *pZip_filename, const char
     189             :    *pArchive_name, const void *pBuf, size_t buf_size, const void *pComment, mz_uint16 comment_size,
     190             :    mz_uint level_and_flags);
     191             : 
     192             :      The archive will be created if it doesn't already exist, otherwise it'll be appended to.
     193             :      Note the appending is done in-place and is not an atomic operation, so if something goes wrong
     194             :      during the operation it's possible the archive could be left without a central directory
     195             :    (although the local file headers and file data will be fine, so the archive will be recoverable).
     196             : 
     197             :      For more complex archive modification scenarios:
     198             :      1. The safest way is to use a mz_zip_reader to read the existing archive, cloning only those
     199             :    bits you want to preserve into a new archive using using the mz_zip_writer_add_from_zip_reader()
     200             :    function (which compiles the compressed file data as-is). When you're done, delete the old
     201             :    archive and rename the newly written archive, and you're done. This is safe but requires a bunch
     202             :    of temporary disk space or heap memory.
     203             : 
     204             :      2. Or, you can convert an mz_zip_reader in-place to an mz_zip_writer using
     205             :    mz_zip_writer_init_from_reader(), append new files as needed, then finalize the archive which
     206             :    will write an updated central directory to the original archive. (This is basically what
     207             :    mz_zip_add_mem_to_archive_file_in_place() does.) There's a possibility that the archive's central
     208             :    directory could be lost with this method if anything goes wrong, though.
     209             : 
     210             :      - ZIP archive support limitations:
     211             :      No zip64 or spanning support. Extraction functions can only handle unencrypted, stored or
     212             :    deflated files. Requires streams capable of seeking.
     213             : 
     214             :    * This is a header file library, like stb_image.c. To get only a header file, either cut and
     215             :    paste the below header, or create miniz.h, #define MINIZ_HEADER_FILE_ONLY, and then include
     216             :    miniz.c from it.
     217             : 
     218             :    * Important: For best perf. be sure to customize the below macros for your target platform:
     219             :      #define MINIZ_USE_UNALIGNED_LOADS_AND_STORES 1
     220             :      #define MINIZ_LITTLE_ENDIAN 1
     221             :      #define MINIZ_HAS_64BIT_REGISTERS 1
     222             : 
     223             :    * On platforms using glibc, Be sure to "#define _LARGEFILE64_SOURCE 1" before including miniz.c
     224             :    to ensure miniz uses the 64-bit variants: fopen64(), stat64(), etc. Otherwise you won't be able
     225             :    to process large files (i.e. 32-bit stat() fails for me on files > 0x7FFFFFFF bytes).
     226             : */
     227             : 
     228             : #ifndef MINIZ_HEADER_INCLUDED
     229             : #define MINIZ_HEADER_INCLUDED
     230             : 
     231             : #include <stdlib.h>
     232             :

     311             : // ------------------- zlib-style API Definitions.
     312             : 
     313             : // For more compatibility with zlib, miniz.c uses unsigned long for some parameters/struct members.
     314             : // Beware: mz_ulong can be either 32 or 64-bits!
     315             : typedef unsigned long mz_ulong;
     316             : 
     317             : // mz_free() internally uses the MZ_FREE() macro (which by default calls free() unless you've
     318             : // modified the MZ_MALLOC macro) to release a block allocated from the heap.
     319             : void mz_free(void *p);
     320             : 
     321             : #define MZ_ADLER32_INIT (1)
     322             : // mz_adler32() returns the initial adler-32 value to use when called with ptr==NULL.

     324             :

     328             : 
     329             : // Compression strategies.

     339             : // unsigned long.

     341             : typedef void (*mz_free_func)(void *opaque, void *address);

     390             : struct mz_internal_state;
     391             : 
     392             : // Compression/decompression stream struct.
     393             : typedef struct mz_stream_s {
     394             :     const unsigned char *next_in;  // pointer to next byte to read
     395             :     unsigned int avail_in;         // number of bytes available at next_in
     396             :     mz_ulong total_in;             // total number of bytes consumed so far
     397             : 
     398             :     unsigned char *next_out;  // pointer to next byte to write
     399             :     unsigned int avail_out;   // number of bytes that can be written to next_out
     400             :     mz_ulong total_out;       // total number of bytes produced so far
     401             : 
     402             :     char *msg;                        // error msg (unused)
     403             :     struct mz_internal_state *state;  // internal state, allocated by zalloc/zfree
     404             : 
     405             :     mz_alloc_func zalloc;  // optional heap allocation function (defaults to malloc)
     406             :     mz_free_func zfree;    // optional heap free function (defaults to free)

     446             : // mz_deflate() compresses the input to output, consuming as much of the input and producing as much
     447             : // output as possible. Parameters:
     448             : //   pStream is the stream to read from and write to. You must initialize/update the next_in,
     449             : //   avail_in, next_out, and avail_out members. flush may be MZ_NO_FLUSH,
     450             : //   MZ_PARTIAL_FLUSH/MZ_SYNC_FLUSH, MZ_FULL_FLUSH, or MZ_FINISH.
     451             : // Return values:
     452             : //   MZ_OK on success (when flushing, or if more input is needed but not available, and/or there's
     453             : //   more output to be written but the output buffer is full). MZ_STREAM_END if all input has been
     454             : //   consumed and all output bytes have been written. Don't call mz_deflate() on the stream anymore.
     455             : //   MZ_STREAM_ERROR if the stream is bogus.
     456             : //   MZ_PARAM_ERROR if one of the parameters is invalid.
     457             : //   MZ_BUF_ERROR if no forward progress is possible because the input and/or output buffers are
     458             : //   empty. (Fill up the input buffer or free up some output space and try again.)

     488             : int mz_inflateInit2(mz_streamp pStream, int window_bits);
     489             : 
     490             : // Decompresses the input stream to the output, consuming only as much of the input as needed, and
     491             : // writing as much to the output as possible. Parameters:
     492             : //   pStream is the stream to read from and write to. You must initialize/update the next_in,
     493             : //   avail_in, next_out, and avail_out members. flush may be MZ_NO_FLUSH, MZ_SYNC_FLUSH, or
     494             : //   MZ_FINISH. On the first call, if flush is MZ_FINISH it's assumed the input and output buffers
     495             : //   are both sized large enough to decompress the entire stream in a single call (this is slightly
     496             : //   faster). MZ_FINISH implies that there are no more source bytes available beside what's already
     497             : //   in the input buffer, and that the output buffer is large enough to hold the rest of the
     498             : //   decompressed data.
     499             : // Return values:
     500             : //   MZ_OK on success. Either more input is needed but not available, and/or there's more output to
     501             : //   be written but the output buffer is full. MZ_STREAM_END if all needed input has been consumed
     502             : //   and all output bytes have been written. For zlib streams, the adler-32 of the decompressed data
     503             : //   has also been verified. MZ_STREAM_ERROR if the stream is bogus. MZ_DATA_ERROR if the deflate
     504             : //   stream is invalid. MZ_PARAM_ERROR if one of the parameters is invalid. MZ_BUF_ERROR if no
     505             : //   forward progress is possible because the input buffer is empty but the inflater needs more
     506             : //   input to continue, or if the output buffer is not large enough. Call mz_inflate() again with
     507             : //   more input data, or with more room in the output buffer (except when using single call
     508             : //   decompression, described above).
     509             : int mz_inflate(mz_streamp pStream, int flush);
     510             : 
     511             : // Deinitializes a decompressor.
     512             : int mz_inflateEnd(mz_streamp pStream);

     855             : // ------------------- Low-level Decompression API Definitions
     856             : 
     857             : // Decompression flags used by tinfl_decompress().
     858             : // TINFL_FLAG_PARSE_ZLIB_HEADER: If set, the input has a valid zlib header and ends with an adler32
     859             : // checksum (it's a valid zlib stream). Otherwise, the input is a raw deflate stream.
     860             : // TINFL_FLAG_HAS_MORE_INPUT: If set, there are more input bytes available beyond the end of the
     861             : // supplied input buffer. If clear, the input buffer contains all remaining input.
     862             : // TINFL_FLAG_USING_NON_WRAPPING_OUTPUT_BUF: If set, the output buffer is large enough to hold the
     863             : // entire decompressed stream. If clear, the output buffer is at least the size of the dictionary
     864             : // (typically 32KB). TINFL_FLAG_COMPUTE_ADLER32: Force adler-32 checksum computation of the
     865             : // decompressed bytes.
     866             : enum {
     867             :     TINFL_FLAG_PARSE_ZLIB_HEADER = 1,
     868             :     TINFL_FLAG_HAS_MORE_INPUT = 2,
     869             :     TINFL_FLAG_USING_NON_WRAPPING_OUTPUT_BUF = 4,
     870             :     TINFL_FLAG_COMPUTE_ADLER32 = 8
     871             : };
     872             : 
     873             : // High level decompression functions:
     874             : // tinfl_decompress_mem_to_heap() decompresses a block in memory to a heap block allocated via
     875             : // malloc(). On entry:
     876             : //  pSrc_buf, src_buf_len: Pointer and size of the Deflate or zlib source data to decompress.
     877             : // On return:
     878             : //  Function returns a pointer to the decompressed data, or NULL on failure.
     879             : //  *pOut_len will be set to the decompressed data's size, which could be larger than src_buf_len on
     880             : //  uncompressible data. The caller must call mz_free() on the returned block when it's no longer
     881             : //  needed.
     882             : void *tinfl_decompress_mem_to_heap(const void *pSrc_buf, size_t src_buf_len, size_t *pOut_len,
     883             :                                    int flags);
     884             : 
     885             : // tinfl_decompress_mem_to_mem() decompresses a block in memory to another block in memory.
     886             : // Returns TINFL_DECOMPRESS_MEM_TO_MEM_FAILED on failure, or the number of bytes written on success.
     887             : #define TINFL_DECOMPRESS_MEM_TO_MEM_FAILED ((size_t)(-1))

     889             :                                    size_t src_buf_len, int flags);

     968             : 
     969             : // ------------------- Low-level Compression API Definitions
     970             : 
     971             : // Set TDEFL_LESS_MEMORY to 1 to use less memory (compression will be slightly slower, and
     972             : // raw/dynamic blocks will be output more frequently).
     973             : #define TDEFL_LESS_MEMORY 0
     974             : 
     975             : // tdefl_init() compression flags logically OR'd together (low 12 bits contain the max. number of
     976             : // probes per dictionary search): TDEFL_DEFAULT_MAX_PROBES: The compressor defaults to 128
     977             : // dictionary probes per dictionary search. 0=Huffman only, 1=Huffman+LZ (fastest/crap compression),
     978             : // 4095=Huffman+LZ (slowest/best compression).
     979             : enum { TDEFL_HUFFMAN_ONLY = 0, TDEFL_DEFAULT_MAX_PROBES = 128, TDEFL_MAX_PROBES_MASK = 0xFFF };
     980             : 
     981             : // TDEFL_WRITE_ZLIB_HEADER: If set, the compressor outputs a zlib header before the deflate data,
     982             : // and the Adler-32 of the source data at the end. Otherwise, you'll get raw deflate data.
     983             : // TDEFL_COMPUTE_ADLER32: Always compute the adler-32 of the input data (even when not writing zlib
     984             : // headers). TDEFL_GREEDY_PARSING_FLAG: Set to use faster greedy parsing, instead of more efficient
     985             : // lazy parsing. TDEFL_NONDETERMINISTIC_PARSING_FLAG: Enable to decrease the compressor's
     986             : // initialization time to the minimum, but the output may vary from run to run given the same input
     987             : // (depending on the contents of memory). TDEFL_RLE_MATCHES: Only look for RLE matches (matches with
     988             : // a distance of 1) TDEFL_FILTER_MATCHES: Discards matches <= 5 chars if enabled.
     989             : // TDEFL_FORCE_ALL_STATIC_BLOCKS: Disable usage of optimized Huffman tables.
     990             : // TDEFL_FORCE_ALL_RAW_BLOCKS: Only use raw (uncompressed) deflate blocks.
     991             : // The low 12 bits are reserved to control the max # of hash probes per dictionary lookup (see
     992             : // TDEFL_MAX_PROBES_MASK).
     993             : enum {
     994             :     TDEFL_WRITE_ZLIB_HEADER = 0x01000,
     995             :     TDEFL_COMPUTE_ADLER32 = 0x02000,
     996             :     TDEFL_GREEDY_PARSING_FLAG = 0x04000,
     997             :     TDEFL_NONDETERMINISTIC_PARSING_FLAG = 0x08000,
     998             :     TDEFL_RLE_MATCHES = 0x10000,
     999             :     TDEFL_FILTER_MATCHES = 0x20000,
    1000             :     TDEFL_FORCE_ALL_STATIC_BLOCKS = 0x40000,
    1001             :     TDEFL_FORCE_ALL_RAW_BLOCKS = 0x80000
    1002             : };
    1003             : 
    1004             : // High level compression functions:
    1005             : // tdefl_compress_mem_to_heap() compresses a block in memory to a heap block allocated via malloc().
    1006             : // On entry:
    1007             : //  pSrc_buf, src_buf_len: Pointer and size of source block to compress.
    1008             : //  flags: The max match finder probes (default is 128) logically OR'd against the above flags.
    1009             : //  Higher probes are slower but improve compression.
    1010             : // On return:

    1013             : //  uncompressible data. The caller must free() the returned block when it's no longer needed.
